results.name: Decimal expansion of [3, 3, ...] = (3 + sqrt(13))/2.
comment: For reasons following from the formula section, this constant could be called "the bronze ratio". For this, compare with A001622 and A014176.
This is the shape of a 3-extension rectangle; see A188640 for definitions. - _Clark Kimberling_, Apr 10 2011
An analog of Fermat theorem: for prime p, round(c^p) == 3 (mod p).
A generalization for "metallic" constants c_N = (N+sqrt(N^2+4))/2, N>=1: for prime p, round((c_N)^p) == N (mod p). (End)
link: G. C. Greubel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: 3 plus the constant in A085550. - _R. J. Mathar_, Sep 02 2008
From _Hieronymus Fischer_, Jan 02 2009 (Start): Set c:=(3+sqrt(13))/2. Then the fractional part of c^n equals 1/c^n, if n odd. For even n, the fractional part of c^n is equal to 1-(1/c^n).
c:=(3+sqrt(13))/2 satisfies c-c^(-1)=floor(c)=3, hence c^n + (-c)^(-n) = round(c^n) for n>0, which follows from the general formula of A001622.
See A001622 for a general formula concerning the fractional parts of powers of numbers x>1, which satisfy x-x^(-1)=floor(x).
Other examples of constants x satisfying the relation x-x^(-1)=floor(x) include A001622 (the golden ratio: where floor(x)=1) and A014176 (the silver ratio: where floor(x)=2).

A generalization for "metallic" constants c_N = (N+sqrt(N^2+4))/2, N>=1. Let {A_N(n), n>=0} be the sequence 0, 1, N, N^2+1, N^3+2*N, N^4+3*N^2+1,..., a(N) = N*a(N-1) + a(N-2). Then c_N = N + sum_{n>=1} (-1)^(n-1)/(A_N(n)*A_N(n+1)) (cf. A001622, A014176, A098316, A098317, A098318). - _Vladimir Shevelev_, Feb 23 2013
